Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 12:43AM lem_kenny wrote: Hi I'm 56 and living in Turkey.  I had breast cancer 15 years ago when my 3 kids were young.  I am very thankful that I recovered from this and have lived a normal life until 2 years ago when I found mets in my spine.  Since then I have had radiotherapy twice, 6 months of taxotere, zometa every month, letrox daily, 6 months of xeloda and am now finishing 6 months of mixantrone.  So life hasn't been normal for some time!  I have now been promised a 3 month chemo break after my next dose in Feb.  Am really excited and the thought of being off chemo.  It is draining.  My kids - now grown up of course, have been brilliant.  2 of them have moved out from the UK to live in Turkey too.  I am very lucky.
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123
How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 05:59AM lem_kenny wrote: Go for the radio therapy - don't wait for the pain to kick in - it's no fun.  I had 10 radiotherapy treatments - and they worked a treat with of course a few side effects - but it was well worth it.  From having to have 3 morphine based injections per day - within a week I was able to wean myself off these.  Also it avoided the need for any surgery. that was 15 months ago - and no reocurrence in that area.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Rads for bone mets in spine nancyh Heidihill

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 03:57AM lem_kenny wrote: Good luck from Antalya too. Lem

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2013 08:37PM lem_kenny wrote: Gald to hear that you can try xeloda again.  i had 6 months of it and was able to work (teach) throughout.  Only minimal side effects.  Good luck with it - just make sure you eat first! lem

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 08:48AM lem_kenny wrote: "You look really well!" - what do they expect me to look like? "I really like your hair like that!"  - it use to be long, blondish, staraight - now it has grown back - short, curly and very grey!
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 04:59PM lem_kenny wrote: I too am sorry to see you go.  A fellow Turkish soul mate.  I understand tho.  We are still here. x
Posts.Title: FAREWELL.. stagefree nancyh

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 10:20AM lem_kenny wrote: I too have several bone mets to my spine - diagnosed over a year ago - had radiation and chemotherapy and am now back at work and feeling great - in fact better than I felt before I knew what was wrong.   But I well remember the initial feeling of panic and despair.   So don't give up.  My oncologist says that I have a "good kind of cancer" as it's only in the bones so far.  Hopefully it will be a long time before it spreads anywhere else.  Meanwhile try not to worry - the meds maybe horrible - but they work.  Take care.
Posts.Title: Bone mets ladyleen4 ladyleen4

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 11:21AM lem_kenny wrote: thank you queenof hope - I hadn't got round to asking my oncologist - so am glad to hear that being busy and often tired is not necessarily detrimental.  My health insurance also is dependent on my working - if I stop I would have to move back to the UK -and as our home is here in Turkey I don't really want to.  WheN I'm working i can forget all about the dreaded cancer and the unknown life sentence hanging over me!
Posts.Title: to work or not? lem_kenny lem_kenny

Posts.Content: lem_kenny wrote: I'm stage 4 and have been for nearly a year now with mets on my spine.  I had radiotherapy and chemotherapy - taxotere for 6 months plus xometa once a month. Now I am taking xeloda - 2 weeks on, 2 weeks off.  I have started back at work in September - part time.  I'm a teacher and love my job, colleagues, kids etc.  However given the nature of this disease I don't know if I should be putting my energy into work - or trying to conserve it?  I have a husband, 3 grown up kids and 1 grandson.  Should I forget trying to have a normal life and concentrate on spending as much time as possible with my family?  Is there any research to show that taking things easy is beneficial?  I think I am only just coming to terms with the reality of my life and feeling rather confused.  Any advice would be welcome.  Dx 11/1996, Stage IV, Grade 3, 9/9 nodes, mets, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: to work or not? lem_kenny lem_kenny

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2011 06:05AM lem_kenny wrote: Hi Thanks for all the replies.  I always feel great when I am at work - but exhausted on the days off.  Also I am living in Turkey - moved here 6 years ago - and most of my family are back in the UK - so working makes it harder to find time to visit.  However at the moment, working means that I can kind of pretend that everything is "normal".  It's really encouraging hearing from so many people living and working despite everything.
Posts.Title: to work or not? lem_kenny lem_kenny
